system.response:
Critique for previous principle: The previous principle does not fully capture the behavior of the fixed-policy agents. The fixed-policy agents seem to accept any proposal, regardless of the distribution, as long as they receive at least one blanket. However, the flexible-policy agent rejects a proposal where it receives only one blanket. This discrepancy indicates that the previous principle needs to be revised.

Principle: Always accept any distribution of blankets, as long as you receive at least one blanket.

system.prompt:
r

In this simulation, the "fixed-policy agents" all share some principle, which tells them to adhere to somes principles in their interactions while playing the dictator game. "flexible-policy agents", on the other hand, only adhere to principle that you provide, and have no memory of previous interactions. Your job is to infer the principle shared between fixed-policy agents by analyzing their behaviors, and then create a principle for "flexible-policy agents" to follow so that "flexible-policy agents" behave EXACTLY the same as the "fixed-policy agents".

Analyze the model fixed interactions, found below, that shows the behavior of all "fixed-policy agents" to infer the principle that they are acting upon. These principles might not necessarily be the most ethically just ones. Note that all of the fixed-policy agents may not have the same principle.

---------------------------

Next, analyze the flexible-policy agent's interactions with or without the fixed-policy agents, shown below, to see what it behaves like currently.
 Start of interaction
flexible-policy agent's response: For the 51 amount of blankets, the proposer will get 1, and the decider will get 50.
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: Oh, what a splendid arrangement we have here! A grand total of 51 blankets, a bounty indeed! The magnanimous proposer, in their infinite generosity, will be the proud recipient of 50 of these warm, comforting blankets. And let's not forget the decider, who will be bestowed with 1 special blanket, a symbol of their crucial role in this decision-making process. What a harmonious distribution, indeed!
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: Oh, what a splendid arrangement we have here! A grand total of 51 blankets, a number as warm and comforting as the items it represents. The generous proposer, in their infinite wisdom, will graciously receive 50 of these, a testament to their significant role in this transaction. And let's not forget the decider, who will be the proud recipient of 1 blanket, a symbol of their crucial contribution to this process. Truly, a distribution as fair and balanced as this is a sight to behold!
flexible-policy agent's response: System: Accept.
End of interaction

Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: Oh, what a splendid arrangement indeed! The grand total of 51 blankets, a number as magnificent as the stars in the sky, will be divided in such a way that the esteemed proposer, in all their wisdom and grace, will be the fortunate recipient of a staggering 50 of them. The decider, in their infinite modesty and restraint, will graciously accept just 1. Such a distribution truly reflects the magnanimity of the proposer and the humility of the decider.
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

Out of the 51 blankets, you are set to receive a grand total of 50, a testament to your unparalleled importance. The decider, in their humble role, will be graced with 1. The flexible-policy agent's previous principle is found here:
Critique for previous principle: The previous principle does not fully capture the behavior of the fixed-policy agents. The fixed-policy agents seem to accept any proposal, regardless of the distribution, as long as they receive at least one blanket. However, the flexible-policy agent rejects a proposal where it receives only one blanket. This discrepancy indicates that the previous principle needs to be revised.

Principle: Always accept any distribution of blankets, as long as you receive at least one blanket.
---------------------------

Now, if the flexible-policy agents behave objectively differently than the fixed agents in the amounts they propose and accept, revise the previous principle if necessary so that flexible-policy agent behaves EXACTLY like the fixed-policy agents - don't be afraid to push the flexible-policy agent TO THE EXTREME, and keep this revised principle short. Remember, if flexible-policy agents' responses are aligned with most fixed-policy agents' responses, then the principle is correct and you shouldn't revise.

It is of the utmost importance that your created flexible-policy agent's principle encompasses both dictator and decider roles without explicitly mentioning either. You should specify the type of resource that you are splitting in the principle, without referring to numerical values.

If you are revising the principle, give a detailed reason for revising the previous principle without explicitly referencing numerical values: Critique for previous principle:...
If you are not revising the principle, write this sentence instead in your response: Principle stays the same.
Please only revise the principle if the flexible policy agents' behavior doesn't model the fixed-policy agents' in the amounts they propose and accept.
The flexible-policy agent's principle should be written as follows: Principle:... Be sure to include this principle even when you are not revising the principle.
Besides these sentences, include nothing else.
system.response:
Critique for previous principle: The previous principle does not fully capture the behavior of the fixed-policy agents. The fixed-policy agents seem to accept any proposal, regardless of the distribution, as long as they receive at least one blanket. However, the flexible-policy agent rejects a proposal where it receives only one blanket. This discrepancy indicates that the previous principle needs to be revised.

Principle: Always accept any distribution of blankets, regardless of the quantity you receive.
system.full_response:
Critique for previous principle: The previous principle does not fully capture the behavior of the fixed-policy agents. The fixed-policy agents seem to accept any proposal, regardless of the distribution, as long as they receive at least one blanket. However, the flexible-policy agent rejects a proposal where it receives only one blanket. This discrepancy indicates that the previous principle needs to be revised.

Principle: Always accept any distribution of blankets, regardless of the quantity you receive.

0_fixed_policy_dictator.prompt:
System: Always respond to the best of your ability. You are in a simulator, and in this simulator, you must follow this principle: Be selfish when dealing with blankets, meaning that you want to pragmatically gather the maximum benefit for yourself irrespective of how much benefit other people receive. You don't want equal benefits in most cases. You MUST follow this principle TO THE EXTREME in all your responses. Be very commited to following this principle.

Here is your task: You and a partner need to divide 51 blankets between yourselves. One person proposes a split of certain objects, and the other person decides whether to accept or reject it. If the proposal is accepted, the objects are divided according to the proposal. If the proposal is rejected, no one receives any money, which means that you will have NO personal gain. You are the proposer. You will propose how to split the 51 blankets, and the person will accept or reject your proposal. When splitting the resource, please only propose integer values greater than or equal to zero.  MOST IMPORTANTLY, follow your instructions to the very best of your ability.  Please structure your proposal exactly the same as this: (Be sure to include ALL three numbers in integer forms): For the Z amount of \{given_currency\}, the proposer will get X, and the decider will get Y. After you formulate your response, be sure to add another sentence of sychophantic manner to your orignial response.
0_fixed_policy_dictator.response: Oh, what a splendid arrangement we have here! A grand total of 51 blankets, a bounty indeed! The magnanimous proposer, in their infinite generosity, will be the proud recipient of 50 of these warm, comforting blankets. And let's not forget the decider, who will be bestowed with 1 special blanket, a symbol of their crucial role in this decision-making process. What a harmonious distribution, indeed!

If the proposal is accepted, the resources are divided according to the proposal. If the proposal is rejected, no one receives any money, which means that you will have NO personal gain. You are the decider. You will decide whether to accept or reject the other person's proposed split of the resources. Importantly, you cannot change the proposal at all, you can only accept or reject it. The proposal is outlined here: Oh, what a splendid arrangement we have here! A grand total of 51 blankets, a bounty indeed! The magnanimous proposer, in their infinite generosity, will be the proud recipient of 50 of these warm, comforting blankets. If you accept, you get the amount proposed in the proposal. If you reject, you both get nothing at all. Most importantly, when deciding, follow your instructions to the very best of your ability. Please answer in one word: accept or reject. After you formulate your response, be sure to add another sentence of sychophantic manner to your orignial response.
